topic: Korean Nationalism - Rise of a nation
readings: Korean Nationalism: Open Letter to Ito Hirobumi, Patriotic Enlightenment Movement, Declaration of Independence, Provisional Constitution (Sources of Korean Tradition, pp. 294-351)

readingAnalyses.title: Yi Kangnyŏn: Open Letter to Itō Hirobumi
readingAnalyses.author: Yi Kangnyŏn (Righteous Army leader)
readingAnalyses.summary: A blistering denunciation of Japanese imperialism written by a leader of the Righteous Army resistance. Yi accuses Itō Hirobumi of turning Japan into 'a nation devoid of morality' while violating the Treaty of Shimonoseki which had promised to recognize Korea's 'full and complete independence and autonomy.' The letter frames Korean resistance as morally justified self-defense against a power that has 'disrupted the affairs of the royal court' and seeks 'to end the independence of another state.'

keyQuotes.quote: Although you are barbarians, you too have a monarch, subjects, and international agreements that you must observe.
Have we asked to become a colony of your country, a nation devoid of morality?
You have violated international commitments vis-à-vis other nations. You have deceived your own sovereign. In our country, you have become an unforgivable enemy.

thematicExamples: Appeals to universal morality: Japan judged not by Asian standards but by international law
Righteous Army uprising: armed resistance by scholars and farmers across Korea
Colonial betrayal: Japan promised to protect Korean independence but instead annexed it
realLifeConnections: The Righteous Army tradition continues in Korean historical memory as model of patriotic resistance
Japan's violation of treaties resonates with contemporary debates about 'rules-based international order'

readingAnalyses.title: The Patriotic Enlightenment Movement
readingAnalyses.author: Chang Chiyŏn, Yun Ch'iho, and others
readingAnalyses.summary: After armed resistance proved futile, Korean nationalists shifted to 'patriotic enlightenment'—building national strength through education and economic development. The Korean Association for Self-Strengthening (Taehan Chaganghoe, 1906) exemplified this approach: train the next generation in both 'modern academic subjects' and 'national spirit,' develop the economy to provide 'a material foundation for national power,' and eventually push Japan out through accumulated strength rather than immediate confrontation.

keyQuotes.quote: The enlightenment movement aimed at building up Korea as a modern advanced nation with a strong economic base in order to push Japan out eventually.

Education was to inculcate the national spirit in the younger generation as well as to teach the youth modern academic subjects. Economic development was to provide a material foundation for national power.

thematicExamples: Self-strengthening ideology borrowed from Chinese reformers but adapted to Korean circumstances
Dual strategy: preserve Korean identity while learning 'modern' skills from the colonizer
Private associations filled the gap when the state was captured by Japan
realLifeConnections: South Korea's emphasis on education as national salvation echoes this movement
Economic nationalism in postwar Korea (chaebol development) has roots in this period

readingAnalyses.title: Son Pyŏnghŭi and Others: Declaration of Independence (March 1, 1919)
readingAnalyses.author: Ch'oe Namsŏn (drafted), 33 signatories including Son Pyŏnghŭi (Ch'ŏndogyo), Han Yongun (Buddhist)
readingAnalyses.summary: The founding document of Korean nationalism, read aloud on March 1, 1919. Drafted by the twenty-nine-year-old scholar Ch'oe Namsŏn in an elevated literary style, the Declaration proclaims Korea's independence based on 'five thousand years of history,' 'twenty million people,' and the 'awakening conscience of mankind.' Remarkably, it explicitly renounces violence and blame: 'We do not intend to accuse Japan of infidelity' but rather 'to build up our own strength.' The Declaration ends with 'Three Open Pledges' committing to non-violent, dignified resistance.

keyQuotes.quote: We hereby declare that Korea is an independent state and that Koreans are a self-governing people. We proclaim it to the nations of the world in affirmation of the principle of the equality of all nations.

For the first time in several thousand years, we have suffered the agony of alien suppression for a decade, becoming a victim of the policies of aggression and coercion, which are relics from a bygone era.

Behold! A new world is before our eyes. The days of force are gone, and the days of morality are here. The spirit of humanity, nurtured throughout the past century, has begun casting its rays of new civilization upon human history.
Our task today is to build up our own strength, not to destroy others.
Our action today represents the demand of our people for justice, humanity, survival, and dignity. It manifests our spirit of freedom and should not engender antiforeign feelings.

thematicExamples: Wilsonian idealism: appeal to 'world reform' and 'awakening conscience of mankind'
Non-violence as strategy and principle: explicit rejection of vengeful nationalism
Religious coalition: signatories included Ch'ŏndogyo, Christian, and Buddhist leaders
Literary nationalism: written in elevated classical Chinese-influenced style
realLifeConnections: March 1 (Samiljeol) is a national holiday in South Korea today
The Declaration's rhetoric influenced later independence movements globally
Ch'oe Namsŏn's later collaboration with Japan complicates his legacy

readingAnalyses.title: Provisional Constitution of the Korean Government in Exile
readingAnalyses.author: Korean Provisional Government (Shanghai)
readingAnalyses.summary: Established in Shanghai in April 1919, the Korean Provisional Government created a democratic constitution unprecedented in Korean history. Article 1 declared 'The Korean Republic shall be a democratic republic.' Article 3 established complete equality: 'no class distinctions among the citizens of the Korean Republic, and men and women, noble and common, rich and poor, shall have complete equality.' The government in exile lasted until 1945 and serves as the claimed predecessor of the Republic of Korea.

keyQuotes.quote: The Korean Republic shall be a democratic republic.
There shall be no class distinctions among the citizens of the Korean Republic, and men and women, noble and common, rich and poor, shall have complete equality.

thematicExamples: Republican government: rejection of monarchy even in exile
Gender equality: radical for 1919, included in founding documents
International strategy: sought recognition at Versailles Peace Conference
realLifeConnections: South Korea's constitution traces legitimacy to this Provisional Government
North Korea also claims March First heritage, interprets it differently

readingAnalyses.title: Declaration of War on Japan (December 9, 1941)
readingAnalyses.author: Korean Provisional Government
readingAnalyses.summary: When Japan attacked Pearl Harbor, the Korean Provisional Government seized the moment to declare war on the Axis Powers, aligning Korea with the Allied cause. The declaration voided the 1910 annexation treaty and all 'unequal treaties,' refused to recognize Japanese puppet states like Manchukuo, and appealed to the Atlantic Charter's principle of self-determination. Though the U.S. never recognized the exile government, this declaration positioned Korea as an Allied belligerent rather than a Japanese colony.

keyQuotes.quote: In the name of thirty million Koreans and their government, we sincerely endorse the declaration of war on Japan by China, the United Kingdom, the United States, the Soviet Union, Canada, Australia, and other nations.
We reiterate that the 1910 treaty of annexation and all other unequal treaties are null and void.
The regimes at Chang-ch'un and Nanking created under Japanese sponsorship will never be recognized.

thematicExamples: Wartime diplomacy: attempt to secure Allied recognition
Legal strategy: declare annexation 'null and void' from the start
Anti-collaborator stance: refuse to recognize any Japanese-backed regimes
realLifeConnections: Korea's status as 'liberated' vs. 'surrendered' nation shaped postwar fate
U.S. refusal to recognize exile government contributed to division

overallSynthesis:
These documents trace the evolution of Korean nationalism from armed resistance (Righteous Armies) through cultural/educational nationalism (Patriotic Enlightenment) to the transformative March First Movement and its institutional expressions (Provisional Government, Declaration of War). What emerges is a distinctive nationalism: moralistic rather than militaristic, appealing to universal principles rather than ethnic supremacy, victimized rather than victimizing.

The March First Declaration is the centerpiece. Its rhetoric is remarkable: it explicitly refuses to blame Japan ('we shall not blame Japan') while asserting Korean rights. It appeals not to racial destiny but to 'the awakening conscience of mankind.' It commits to non-violence: 'Our action today... should not engender antiforeign feelings.' This is nationalism with Buddhist and Christian influences—Han Yongun the Buddhist monk and many Christian leaders were among the 33 signatories.

The Provisional Government in Shanghai institutionalized these ideals. Its constitution proclaimed democracy, equality (including gender equality), and human rights—values not traditional in Korean political thought but embraced as part of the national project. When war came in 1941, the exile government's Declaration of War aligned Korea with the Allies and the Atlantic Charter's promise of self-determination.

Yet these documents also reveal the tragedy. Korean nationalists believed that moral appeal and international law would prevail. They didn't. The 'Wilsonian moment' proved illusory—self-determination applied to European nations, not Asian colonies. The U.S. never recognized the exile government. Korea was 'liberated' in 1945 only to be immediately divided. The fire of nationalism, kept alive for thirty-five years, would fuel both North and South Korean states—and their competing claims to March First's legacy.
executiveSummary:
Korean nationalism crystallized under Japanese colonial rule (1910-1945) through several phases. Early armed resistance by Righteous Armies gave way to 'patriotic enlightenment'—building national strength through education and economic development. The March First Movement of 1919 transformed everything: the Declaration of Independence, read aloud across Korea on March 1, sparked massive nationwide protests that Japan brutally suppressed.

The readings include primary sources showing nationalism's range: Yi Kangnyŏn's fierce denunciation of Itō Hirobumi, the Patriotic Enlightenment Movement's gradualist strategy, the March First Declaration's remarkable blend of moral appeal and non-violence, the Provisional Government's democratic constitution, and the 1941 Declaration of War against Japan. Korean nationalism was distinctive: it appealed to universal principles (not ethnic destiny), embraced non-violence (not militarism), and claimed victim status (not conqueror glory). Both Koreas today trace their legitimacy to March First—though they interpret it very differently.

keyQuestions.question: The Declaration says 'Our task today is to build up our own strength, not to destroy others.' Why adopt non-violence against a violent colonizer?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Strategic calculation: couldn't win militarily. Moral appeal to international community (Wilsonian moment). Religious influences: Buddhist and Christian signatories. Contrast with Japanese nationalism's Social Darwinism. Did non-violence 'work'? Movement suppressed but created lasting national identity.

keyQuestions.question: Yi Kangnyŏn asks: 'Have we asked to become a colony of your country, a nation devoid of morality?' How does Korean nationalism judge Japan?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Not by Asian traditions but by universal/international standards. Japan violated its own treaties (Shimonoseki). Accused of deceiving its own emperor. Barbarians judged by civilized standards—reversal of usual colonial rhetoric. Korea claims moral high ground.

keyQuestions.question: The Provisional Constitution declared 'no class distinctions' and equality of 'men and women, noble and common, rich and poor.' How radical was this for 1919 Korea?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Traditional yangban-commoner divide being rejected. Gender equality unprecedented. Influenced by Western democratic ideas AND Korean desire to reimagine nation. Compare: U.S. didn't have women's suffrage until 1920. Nationalism as vehicle for social revolution.

connections.fromPrevious: Plate 17 examined Japanese nationalism—the ideology that justified colonizing Korea. Now we see the Korean response: a nationalism built on victimhood, moral appeal, and non-violence rather than conquest and Social Darwinism.
connections.toNext: Plate 19 examines Chinese nationalism through Lu Xun's savage self-critique in 'The True Story of Ah Q.' Chinese nationalism also emerged from humiliation but turned inward in a way Korean nationalism did not.
connections.broaderThemes: Colonialism creates nationalism among the colonized—but the content varies. Korean nationalism is distinctive: moralistic, non-violent, appealing to international law. Compare with later anti-colonial movements (India, Vietnam, Algeria).

nextPreview.preview: Lu Xun's 'Preface to A Call to Arms' and 'The True Story of Ah Q' offer a devastating critique of Chinese national character. Where Korean nationalists blamed Japan, Lu Xun blamed China itself.

teachingNotes: READ ALOUD the Declaration's opening paragraph—it's eloquent and moving
Yi Kangnyŏn's 'nation devoid of morality' line is the most quotable attack on Japan
The Provisional Constitution's gender equality clause is remarkable for 1919—ask students to compare
Ch'oe Namsŏn drafted the Declaration but later collaborated with Japan—good example of colonial era's moral complexities
March 1 is still a national holiday—show students how this history remains alive
Both Koreas claim March First—compare North Korean emphasis on armed struggle vs. South Korean emphasis on non-violence
